text: So, I tried out Donkey Kong country for the first time today. When I came to this level, I had to pause the game for a moment and say out loud "Why is this music so beautiful?". So, besides the amazing soundtrack, the gameplay is very fun and the graphics very impressive, and the difficulty seems perfect so far. I understand now why so many people consider this game a masterpiece. I wish there would still be musics composed in the style of the SNES and N64. The lack of instruments composers had to put up with is what made beautiful pieces like this. Sure, it's not an epic orhestra or the peak of rock and metal, but it's just as amazing.

text:
This track is even more amazing when you read into the backstory of how it was created.  The SNES only had 64K of audio memory, which meant that tracks like this aren't actually complete audio tracks - they are individual notes painstakingly sequenced to create the illusion of music while fitting in that 64K.

In the case of Aquatic Ambience, it was five weeks of hard work to get what you hear in this clip.

Nowadays this track would just have been recorded as a straight audio file such as WAV or MP3.

author: soulassassin0g

text:
i can understand man. I swing between big times of nostalgia and times where i don't think of it. Funny how we share feelings with people living all over the world eh?

I've played the hell out of DKC when i was around 5-6 years old at my cousin's house. They lived in this big house on a hill near perugia (center of italy).

Since they are 10 years older than me they had all kind of consoles from the 80's and 90's. Snes was one of 'em. I always miss the feeling of dwelling in their living room furniture,stumbling on a box containing games and consoles. I miss that house. I went back to them last year. And all the upper floor where i used to play,well,they were restructuring the place. All gone. i hated it. it was like losing a part of my childhood. I wanted to share this memory with you,and it's funny thinking that while i know perfectly what i'm talking about,you just can imagine and wonder how that place was. But i feel good having talked to you about this. Care to share a memory too? :)
author: Federico Sgamma

text: @Federico Sgamma that was beautiful. Okay, I'll share something with you. I remember growing up in the early 90's and it was a beautiful time to live. I lived in an apartment complex in a great neighborhood, where there's lots of children playing around, people would walk around and greet one another, and it felt like everyone knew each other and they got along. I remember playing DKC for the first time on the SNES there, the kids of the complex would always gather around the same place and talk about strategies and tips on how to beat the game, not just DKC but on any game, it was like the internet only better. Sometimes we would go around to each others houses, bouncing around the living room, causing a ruckus, and play two players games taking turns passing the controller around. Nowadays everyone stays home, they get online, and talk to their friends by sending words over a screen or talking to them through a microphone. I miss having conversation in person. These kids today don't know what or how it feels to actually socialize.
author: soulassassin0g

text:
I find it true. out of curiosity,where you from?Â 

Here in italy not all the kids had a blast with games. General opinion was more "meh/they are harmful".Â 

I still did some gathering of kids at school talking about games. There was a kid who was doing last year at elementary while i was smaller that talked to me about ocarina of time around 1998. I was seven and i was blown away by all the small details he told to me. I still remember him rushing to me (guess i was very curious about games,so he enjoyed telling me his progress) one day telling me "hey,you can't imagine what i discovered yesterday! if you play a song on the ocarina you can make scarecrows dance!"

Silly,yes,but that thing had a powerful impact on my imagination. I can make scarecrow dance in a game? i want to do it.

Even if i don't speak to my dad in a long time over some finance issues nowadays,i'm still grateful to him for buying me a nes,a snes and a nintendo 64. The latter was his last gift while he and my mom were together. The unboxing under the christmas tree with diddy kong racing was...magical. I think it was the first time in my life that i spent being awake into the middle of the night. and i felt afraid of breaking a rule just to play. Eh,it was basically almost 20 years ago. Of course pokemon changed everything. Suddendly every kid fussed to get a gameboy. Even me of course.

Another good memory is my dad buying a pc with windows 95. being a huge strategy fan he played command & conquer every night while i fell asleep. He did this up to tiberian sun in later years,when i was around ten years old. It's so silly that we do not talk anymore after all this nice memories. I wonder if he think about them as i do.

The turning point,i guess,was receiving metal gear solid on christmas 1999. My cousin,the same of that house i talked about gave it to me. i still remember that he played the game already. And he was stunningly amazed by it.
Â he was talking to my dad about the themes of the game. He had never seen so much in a game before. My dad took an interest too in the game since my cousin told some of the plot (my dad enjoyed a lot being in the army while young). but sadly never played it. Silly dad,he would have loved it

I played the game,and even if the plot was real thick for a kid of my age,it felt simple thanks to it's "anime" style.Â 

there's so much i could talk about relating to videogames and childhood. nowadays i find harder and harder to get into games like when i was still a kid. But hell,everytime some people tell me "you're such a nerd,playing videogames so much" i always feel a sense of proudness. i know some people who tend to hide this hobby like it's something silly. I did it too thanks to some pricks in intermediary school. But now i just don't care. it's beautiful,and i think that videogames are a beautiful way of telling a story if developers do their job well. MGS taught me a lot about the sense of freedom,being who you really are and this kind of themes. And in someway i really miss those times when it was just a hobby for not everyone. there was something special about it.

one last memory: there was a videogame shop in my town. Dad used to bring me there to rent games. i remember clearly the cover art for secret of mana. I wanted that game so badly. but the owner said to me "it's an rpg,you're probably too young to handle it,try again in some time". So i ended up renting Yoshi's Island.Â 

It was the best thing ever. And everytime i hear that carillon theme,it moves me. It's just the sound of my childhood in some way. I'm happy to have shared this things with you. Believe me,i never did it with anyone. But i ended up doing it now because of Aquatic Ambiance. I don't know if David Wise knows it,but hell,his music really opens doors leading into sharing nostalgia with other people. I would love to tell him "thanks man".

and of course,thanks to you. It felt good to do it. (oh,sorry if i bored you,i just went on and on and on and on)

author: Federico Sgamma

text:
+soulassassin0g +Federico Sgamma
I really enjoyed reading your guys' conversation. I agree and feel so much similarity with both of your stories. It is difficult for me to listen to this song without tearing up. The memories of the innocence and joy of childhood in the 90's. Technology, and specifically video games, were means of exploration and escape back then; you could feel and experience the heart of the game makers and composers almost. Now days technology is simply a tool to control the masses, or make people's lives a little bit easier. Easier isn't always better though.

And it wasn't just video games, it was the culture. People born post-2000 honestly wouldn't understand (I was born in 1992). From everything like television shows like Rugrats, Hey Arnold!, Double Dare 2000, etc, to movies like Spy Kids, entertainment provided wholesome and truly emotionally affecting experiences. I watched an episode of The Wild Thornberry's last week, which was the first time I had seen that show in probably 10-15 years, and it was everything and more that I remembered. The glory days of animation. 

My experience with video games is an unusual one, in that I haven't owned a new console since the Playstation 2. Games and consoles made since then simply do not intrigue me any longer. It all began with the SNES for me, with Donkey Kong Country. There are also numerous joyous memories with Windows 95-98 (a lot of children games with my two cousins), N64 (DK 64, Mario Kart, 1080 Snowboarding, Tony Hawk), Playstation 2 (Downhill Domination), Gamecube (Sunshine Mario), Gameboy Advance/SP (Tony Hawk, Crash Bandicoot, Mario). The only game I have played since then is BZFlag for PC, a wonderful open-source tank game from the 90's, though now days there is little to no online activity.

I wish everyday that I could return to my childhood in the late 90's. "Aquatic Ambience" and a few other tracks transport me back there, even if only for a few minutes, a few moments at a time. I believe one day, somehow, someway, I will get to experience those moments again, whether here, or beyond this life. I love you both, my fellow 90s kids! :)

text:
@liquidnature13Â Heh,i can understand you man. I was born in 1991. I guess that every generation "idolizes" (although this word would seem to have a negative meaning,i'm not saying it that way) their childood ambient. But i understand what do you say. :)

I can remember clearly 90's cartoons. Dad used to have a cable tv,and it aired some english channels like cartoon network. Back then we didn't had a italian version of it until the 2000's i guess. So i had the chance of watching toons of that years: Dexter's laboratory and all the others by genndy tartakovsky (man,that guy sure has a weird surname)Â 

Courage the cowardly dog,ed edd n'eddy. Man,those were amazing times for toons,i agree.

Sadly i just watched nickelodeon's line up very rarely,had a nickelodeon channel but it was in german,so i couldn't understand anything :P

i have a marvelous memory of going to family friend's house some times. They have a daughter of my same age (we lost contact in the years tho,shame :\ ) who had a pc with MDK on it. It was 97 i guess? Game was simply amazing to my eyes,very weird moments in it. of all games i guess that it shaped my imagination the most with the subtle and no-sense irony of it.Â 

yes,technology has changed,and i agree on the fact that before games used to have more love put in it. Maybe they still do them with love,but...something's different,and you can feel it.Â 

last game that made me feel that sensation of "they put love,so much love in it" was the first hotline miami. It stunned me really

I understand how you feel. Reading this brought tears to my eyes. You soulsummenor, MASTAX1234, myself, and whoever else relates can cherish all of our memories of playing all 3 of the Donkey Kong Country SNES games with our moms. I still remember going to Wal Mart when I was little and buying DKC 3 with my parents. Sweet but successful tear-jerking memories. I already miss my mom a lot thinking of her everyday but this makes me miss her more. But I don't regret remembering those very sweet memories even if they make me cry.

text: I've been deaf since the year 1999, but this song is embed pretty heavily into my skull. I'm kinda surprised by the comments: I thought I was the only person alive who had ever felt an odd twinge of tranquility from listening to this. It's easily my favorite piece of instrumental music,and it takes me back to my youth, back when the SNES was the pinnacle of gaming. These days, N64 is considered a relic, though it was the 'wave of the future' back when I was a teen. Funny how times change. At least I've lived to hear this song. It sums up my childhood nicely.

text:
John Moreira i was reading some of his stories the other day this one stuck out to me and ive been meaning post it here. 

" There is a price we all must pay; no matter how steep the price becomes, a compensation-no prize, no royalty, no exquisite rapture-is ever guaranteed or promised. Sometimes, such as in my case, the price is never met, as though your life is that of servitude, intended to appease an unknown entity like a pawn in chess. Oh, IÃ­ve paid my price for being human, for being me. IÃ­ve paid with close to a dozen mind-numbingly excessive operations, spanning well over fifty hours. IÃ­ve paid with over two yearÃ­s worth of therapy. And today, IÃ­m still paying the price. If the roads you follow are of bliss, cherish them like they were made of the purest of gold, for somewhere, somehow, youÃ­ll fatefully go astray, perhaps so far that your roads of grandeur become your roads of decadence. Once youÃ­re on that road, thereÃ­s no returning, no going home. If you ever find yourself on that road, look around and you just might find me

     Sometimes life just isnÃ­t very kind." 2005 Randy Pendleton

text: I was so young when I got this game and heard this for the first time. When you're a child, you're in a dreamy magical bubble and it's all perfect. My father bought it for me. I asked him to play on the tough levels. The water levels were cool - with the swordfish - and even as a child I recognized how sensual and deep the music was. text:
@FnordPerfect 

Dave Wise produced almost all the music for Rare-produced NES games, like Battletoads, Snake Rattle n Roll, Wizards&Warriors and others. For the SNES he did both Battletoads games, the majority of DKC1, all of DKC2 and a few tracks for DKC3, though none of the level music. He also did Diddy Kong racing for N64 and all of the Game Boy Advance DKC3 music.
